Documentation for this format

Options Sets

Answer options for /70183-9

  • http://loinc.org#LA16758-7 ("Baseline")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18432-7 ("2 hours post treatment")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18433-5 ("24 hrs post onset of symptoms, plus or minus 20 minutes")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18434-3 ("7-10 days")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18435-0 ("3 months")
  • http://loinc.org#LA46-8 ("Other")

Answer options for /70184-7

  • http://loinc.org#LA18436-8 ("Alert, keenly responsive")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18437-6 ("Not alert; but arousable by minor stimulation to obey, answer, or respond")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18438-4 ("Not alert; requires repeated stimulation to attend, or is obtunded and requires strong or painful stimulation to make movements (not stereotyped).")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18439-2 ("Responds only with reflex motor or autonomic effects or totally unresponsive, flaccid, and areflexic.")

Answer options for /70185-4

  • http://loinc.org#LA18440-0 ("Answers both questions correctly")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18441-8 ("Answers one question correctly")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18442-6 ("Answers neither question correctly")

Answer options for /70186-2

  • http://loinc.org#LA18443-4 ("Performs both tasks correctly")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18444-2 ("Performs one task correctly")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18445-9 ("Performs neither task correctly")

Answer options for /70187-0

  • http://loinc.org#LA6626-1 ("Normal")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18446-7 ("Partial gaze palsy; gaze is abnormal in one or both eyes, but forced deviation or total gaze paresis is not present")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18447-5 ("Forced deviation, or total gaze paresis not overcome by the oculocephalic maneuver")

Answer options for /70188-8

  • http://loinc.org#LA18448-3 ("No visual loss")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18449-1 ("Partial hemianopia")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18450-9 ("Complete hemianopia")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18451-7 ("Bilateral hemianopia (blind including cortical blindness)")

Answer options for /70189-6

  • http://loinc.org#LA18452-5 ("Normal symmetrical movements")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18453-3 ("Minor paralysis (flattened nasolabial fold, asymmetry on smiling)")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18454-1 ("Partial paralysis (total or near-total paralysis of lower face)")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18455-8 ("Complete paralysis of one or both sides (absence of facial movement in the upper and lower face)")

Answer options for /70190-4

  • http://loinc.org#LA18456-6 ("No drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees for full 10 seconds")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18457-4 ("Drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees, but drifts down before full 10 seconds; does not hit bed or other support")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18458-2 ("Some effort against gravity; limb cannot get to or maintain (if cued) 90 (or 45) degrees, drifts down to bed, but has some effort against gravity")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18459-0 ("No effort against gravity; limb falls")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18460-8 ("No movement")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18461-6 ("Amputation or joint fusion, explain:")

Answer options for /70967-5

  • http://loinc.org#LA18456-6 ("No drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees for full 10 seconds")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18457-4 ("Drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees, but drifts down before full 10 seconds; does not hit bed or other support")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18458-2 ("Some effort against gravity; limb cannot get to or maintain (if cued) 90 (or 45) degrees, drifts down to bed, but has some effort against gravity")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18459-0 ("No effort against gravity; limb falls")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18460-8 ("No movement")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18461-6 ("Amputation or joint fusion, explain:")

Answer options for /70191-2

  • http://loinc.org#LA18462-4 ("No drift; leg holds 30-degree position for full 5 seconds")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18463-2 ("Drift; leg falls by the end of the 5-second period but does not hit bed")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18464-0 ("Some effort against gravity; leg falls to bed by 5 seconds, but has some effort against gravity")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18465-7 ("No effort against gravity; leg falls to bed immediately")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18460-8 ("No movement")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18461-6 ("Amputation or joint fusion, explain:")

Answer options for /70968-3

  • http://loinc.org#LA18462-4 ("No drift; leg holds 30-degree position for full 5 seconds")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18463-2 ("Drift; leg falls by the end of the 5-second period but does not hit bed")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18464-0 ("Some effort against gravity; leg falls to bed by 5 seconds, but has some effort against gravity")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18465-7 ("No effort against gravity; leg falls to bed immediately")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18460-8 ("No movement")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18461-6 ("Amputation or joint fusion, explain:")

Answer options for /70192-0

  • http://loinc.org#LA9634-2 ("Absent")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18466-5 ("Present in one limb")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18467-3 ("Present in two limbs")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18461-6 ("Amputation or joint fusion, explain:")

Answer options for /70193-8

  • http://loinc.org#LA18468-1 ("Normal; no sensory loss")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18469-9 ("Mild-to-moderate sensory loss; patient feels pinprick is less sharp or is dull on the affected side; or there is a loss of superficial pain with pinprick, but patient is aware of being touched")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18470-7 ("Severe to total sensory loss; patient is not aware of being touched in the face, arm, and leg")

Answer options for /70194-6

  • http://loinc.org#LA18471-5 ("No aphasia; normal")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18472-3 ("Mild-to-moderate aphasia; some obvious loss of fluency or facility of comprehension, without significant limitation on ideas expressed or form of expression")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18473-1 ("Severe aphasia; all communication is through fragmentary expression; great need for inference, questioning, and guessing by the listener")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18474-9 ("Mute, global aphasia; no usable speech or auditory comprehension")

Answer options for /70195-3

  • http://loinc.org#LA6626-1 ("Normal")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18475-6 ("Mild-to-moderate dysarthria; patient slurs at least some words and, at worst, can be understood with some difficulty")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18476-4 ("Severe dysarthria; patient's speech is so slurred as to be unintelligible in the absence of or out of proportion to any dysphasia, or is mute/anarthric")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18477-2 ("Intubated or other physical barrier, explain:")

Answer options for /70196-1

  • http://loinc.org#LA18478-0 ("No abnormality")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18479-8 ("Visual, tactile, auditory, spatial, or personal inattention or extinction to bilateral simultaneous stimulation in one of the sensory modalities")
  • http://loinc.org#LA18480-6 ("Profound hemi-inattention or extinction to more than one modality; does not recognize own hand or orients to only one side of space")

title: NIH Stroke Scale
copyright: Copyright  2006-2016 National Institutes of Health and Northwestern University. Used with permission.

code.display: Agency patient number during assessment period [CMS Assessment]

item.text: Agency-specific patient identifier. This is the identification code the agency assigns to the patient and uses for record keeping purposes for this episode of care.

code.display: NIH stroke scale interval [NIH Stroke Scale]

valueCoding.display: 24 hrs post onset of symptoms, plus or minus 20 minutes
Not alert; but arousable by minor stimulation to obey, answer, or respond
Not alert; requires repeated stimulation to attend, or is obtunded and requires strong or painful stimulation to make movements (not stereotyped).
Responds only with reflex motor or autonomic effects or totally unresponsive, flaccid, and areflexic.

item.text: Tests stimulation and is graded from 0-3
Tests patient's ability to answer questions correctly and is graded from 0-2
Tests patient's ability to perform tasks correctly and is graded from 0-2

valueCoding.display: Partial gaze palsy; gaze is abnormal in one or both eyes, but forced deviation or total gaze paresis is not present
Forced deviation, or total gaze paresis not overcome by the oculocephalic maneuver

item.text: Tests horizontal eye movement and is graded from 0-2
Tests visual fields and is graded from 0-3

valueCoding.display: Minor paralysis (flattened nasolabial fold, asymmetry on smiling)
Partial paralysis (total or near-total paralysis of lower face)
Complete paralysis of one or both sides (absence of facial movement in the upper and lower face)

item.text: Tests the patient's ability to move facial muscles and is graded from 0-3

code.display: Motor arm Left arm [NIH Stroke Scale]

valueCoding.display: No drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees for full 10 seconds
Drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees, but drifts down before full 10 seconds; does not hit bed or other support
Some effort against gravity; limb cannot get to or maintain (if cued) 90 (or 45) degrees, drifts down to bed, but has some effort against gravity
No effort against gravity; limb falls

item.text: Tests motor abilities of the arms and is graded from 0-4

code.display: Motor arm Right arm [NIH Stroke Scale]

valueCoding.display: No drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees for full 10 seconds
Drift; limb holds 90 (or 45) degrees, but drifts down before full 10 seconds; does not hit bed or other support
Some effort against gravity; limb cannot get to or maintain (if cued) 90 (or 45) degrees, drifts down to bed, but has some effort against gravity
No effort against gravity; limb falls

code.display: Motor leg Leg - left [NIH Stroke Scale]

valueCoding.display: No drift; leg holds 30-degree position for full 5 seconds
Drift; leg falls by the end of the 5-second period but does not hit bed
Some effort against gravity; leg falls to bed by 5 seconds, but has some effort against gravity
No effort against gravity; leg falls to bed immediately

item.text: Tests motor abilites of the legs and is graded from 0-4

code.display: Motor leg Leg - right [NIH Stroke Scale]

valueCoding.display: No drift; leg holds 30-degree position for full 5 seconds
Drift; leg falls by the end of the 5-second period but does not hit bed
Some effort against gravity; leg falls to bed by 5 seconds, but has some effort against gravity
No effort against gravity; leg falls to bed immediately

item.text: Tests coordination of muscle movements and is graded from 0-2

valueCoding.display: Mild-to-moderate sensory loss; patient feels pinprick is less sharp or is dull on the affected side; or there is a loss of superficial pain with pinprick, but patient is aware of being touched
Severe to total sensory loss; patient is not aware of being touched in the face, arm, and leg

item.text: Tests sensation of the face, arms. And legs and is graded from 0-2

valueCoding.display: Mild-to-moderate aphasia; some obvious loss of fluency or facility of comprehension, without significant limitation on ideas expressed or form of expression
Severe aphasia; all communication is through fragmentary expression; great need for inference, questioning, and guessing by the listener
Mute, global aphasia; no usable speech or auditory comprehension

item.text: Tests the patient's comprehension and communication and is graded from 0-3

valueCoding.display: Mild-to-moderate dysarthria; patient slurs at least some words and, at worst, can be understood with some difficulty
Severe dysarthria; patient's speech is so slurred as to be unintelligible in the absence of or out of proportion to any dysphasia, or is mute/anarthric
Intubated or other physical barrier, explain:

item.text: Tests patient's speech and is graded from 0-2

valueCoding.display: Visual, tactile, auditory, spatial, or personal inattention or extinction to bilateral simultaneous stimulation in one of the sensory modalities
Profound hemi-inattention or extinction to more than one modality; does not recognize own hand or orients to only one side of space

item.text: Tests patient's recognition of self and is graded from 0-2
Used to gauge the severity of a stroke. Patients are given more points for greater deficiencies. A score of 0 indicates that the test is normal.
